docs.lead_paragraph: Meeting once a month at a rundown union hall here, a dozen temporary workers are trying to ignite a campaign to win for the nation's three million temps the benefits that most permanent workers take for granted, like health insurance, sick pay and paid holidays. The New Jersey workers, working with nonprofit groups here and in half a dozen other states, are drafting a voluntary code of conduct for temp agencies that they say will improve job conditions for the soaring population of temporary workers -- a segment of the labor force that has tripled nationwide in 10 years.

headline.main: Temporary Workers Seeking Code of Conduct for Job Agencies

docs.abstract: Dozen temporary workers, meeting once a week in Hackensack, NJ, are trying to ignite campaign to win for nation's three million temps benefits that most permanent workers take for granted, like health insurance, sick pay and paid holidays; New Jersey workers are drafting voluntary code of conduct for temp agencies that they say will improve job conditions for soaring population of temporary workers; graph; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A woman who once lobbied the White House for improved health insurance has been sentenced to prison for making her daughter so sick that the girl's gall bladder, appendix and part of her intestines had to be removed. The woman, Kathy Bush, who was convicted in October of child abuse and fraud, was sentenced on Friday to five years in prison.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Health Care Advocate Sentenced for Abuse

docs.lead_paragraph: * The Japanese Labor Ministry said it would introduce a new medical insurance program meant to prevent karoshi -- death from overwork. The latest government statistics list 90 such deaths in 1998, up from 32 in 1994. Workers believed to be at greatest risk -- those who are obese, have high blood pressure, high blood sugar and high blood lipid levels -- would get free checkups under the plan.
docs.abstract: Japan to introduce new medical insurance program meant to prevent death from overwork; Danish legislators spar over bill to require pig farms to give pigs daily showers; workers at Lacey, Wash, plagued by droppings from large numbers of seagulls attracted to nearby landfill, carry umbrellas for protection (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hofstra University's Scott Skodnek Business Development Center is home to a polling operation that benefits not only the university but the entire Long Island community. Results from Hofstra's market research and polling are presented regularly in Newsday and News 12 Long Island and in national outlets like ABCNews.com and The San Francisco Examiner. We cover an array of topics, including the economy, child-care issues, home values, New Year's resolutions, auto insurance, race issues, consumer confidence and alternative health care.

headline.main: College Polls Measure Pulse of Island

docs.abstract: Hofstra University market research and polling director Stephanie Bushey and business development center member Scott Skodek letter, responding to January 23 article, notes university's polling operation benefits entire Long Island community (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: With its attacks against Vice President Al Gore's credibility, its use of the bitterly contentious issue of abortion and its targeted appeals to women, former Senator Bill Bradley's campaign today seemed to be engaging more than ever in the kind of political warfare Mr. Bradley has railed against in much of this race. The new strategy clearly seems to be energizing Mr. Bradley's core supporters here, many of whom had complained that his campaign seemed listless in responding to Mr. Gore's hard-charging attacks against his record, health care proposal and partly loyalty.

headline.main: Analysts Question Wisdom of Bradley's New Aggressiveness

docs.abstract: Bill Bradley's sharp-edged assault on Vice Pres Al Gore's honesty just before New Hampshire primary runs risk of tarnishing own image as reformer and may make him seem desperate; strategy seems to be energizing his core supporters in state; some analysts question why he waited so long to push back hard at Gore, whose attacks on him over past several months seem to have undermined his NH support (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A DISPUTE over a proposal to put a Sprint PCS cellular telephone antenna on top of the high school here faced a new challenge earlier this month when two residents filed suit in State Supreme Court in White Plains, questioning the school board's authority to enter into a contract with Sprint. Under a contract the school board and Sprint agreed to in September 1998, Sprint is to pay the district $30,000 the first year of the contract, with increases of 3 percent each year of the remaining nine years of the lease. Some Ossining residents who had objected to the proposal appealed last year to the State Department of Education. The State Education Commissioner, Richard P. Mills, set aside the contract, agreeing with the residents. Sprint challenged that decision in State Supreme Court in White Plains, and the court ruled in Sprint's favor.

headline.main: Suit Filed Over Plan For School Antenna

docs.abstract: Don DeBar and Dr Leslie Plachta file suit questioning authority of school board in Ossining, NY, to enter into contract with Sprint to erect PCS cellular phone atenna atop Ossining High School; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BOARDING a bus on my first day of language school in Santiago, Chile, I spotted a sticker on the plastic partition behind the driver: a green cartoon frog in a circle with a diagonal line through it. ''No se admiten sapos,'' read the caption. To me, a beginner in Spanish, it was a language lesson: picture + words = ''No frogs allowed.'' But why prohibit frogs on buses? I made a note to ask a teacher when I got to my school. For me, every place in the bustling modern city of Santiago was a kind of interactive Spanish class. I was on one of the language-immersion programs that have recently become popular all over Latin America and Europe.
docs.abstract: Edward Hower article on attending Spanish-language immersion course in Santiago, Chile; photos; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The failings of hospital care have suddenly become a hot issue. In November, a much-cited report said that 44,000 to 98,000 patients nationwide died each year because of hospital errors. President Clinton, major corporations and health insurers have seized on that news to call for a major effort to raise the quality of care. But an important step toward improving hospital performance is to measure it -- a complex, politically charged undertaking -- and in this, New York was far in front just a few years ago. A 1996 state law on hospital financing commissioned ''report cards'' on hospitals, assessments that would tell consumers how safe it was to have, say, an appendectomy, or a Caesarean section, at any hospital in New York. Nowhere else had such a thing been attempted.

headline.main: New York State's Ambitious Plan to Grade Hospitals Remains Stalled

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the summer of 1992, a pervasive gloom cast a shadow over the American economy. The unemployment rate rose to 7.8 percent, the worst in years. The Federal Reserve cut interest rates, trying to breathe life into an economy that seemed caught in protracted stagnation. And the federal budget deficit rose to its highest level ever. A best-selling book by a prominent economist, Lester Thurow, reflected a widely held view that the United States would continue to stumble behind a vigorous Japanese economy and a unified Europe. Even President George Bush, who would soon lose his job over the dismal economy, acknowledged that something was wrong.

headline.main: 107 Months, and Counting; Expansion Redefines Economy's Limits

docs.abstract: Economic expansion is set to become longest in United States history in Feb, 107 months; US has turned out to be capable of more growth and less inflation than almost anyone expected when expansion began in 1992; expansion shows most clearly in median family income, which rose to record $46,737 in 1998, adjusted for inflation; income gains have been greatest in work force's upper tier; time line compares lengths of 20th century expansions; graphs compare four decades of economic gains; drawing; photo (L)
